children.subject:
To make it 100% clear: the straight up recommendation for *everyone* is to take EE16A and EE16B.

All the other options are either bugs (e.g. Math 54 and 16A combo) or are intended to make it easier to administratively support corner cases like students who absolutely must take Math 54 for another major. From the perspective of learning what we believe you need to know, students should take EE16AB. As soon as they can in their time at Berkeley. With the standard recommendation being to take 16A in parallel with 61A and 16B in parallel with 61B.

+1

That said, my Math 54 professor went a lot more theoretical with linear algebra and differential equations compared to what I got in EE16A/EE16B, which is good/bad depending on what you're looking for.   But I believe this can vary quite a bit by Math professor (some make 54 more straight-forward and computational).
^ 54 was the worst. As someone who has literally never enjoyed math in college, I'm finding 16A to be beautiful. Wish I had taken it before 70 though
I like this change. Granted I'm a rising senior and I took all 3 of these classes, but 54/16a felt redundant to me. I would have just done 16a/b if I had that option.
Can EECS 47D bridge course be taken as P/NP as well?
Yes, good point. For students who have completed the equivalents to math 54, 47d can also be taken p /np
Just to be 100% sure before switching to P/NP, this is applicable to transfer student with MATH 54 transferred over too?

Yep. 100%. Transfer students who have the equivalent to math 54 can take ee 16a or eecs 47d p/np.

This assumes the math 54 equivalent was taken for a letter grade. Students who do not have math 54 equivalent must either take math 54 or ee 16a for a letter grade.
Note: For new fall 17 junior transfers who've completed an equivalent to math 54 (with letter grades), you are allowed to take ee 16a p/np. EE 16B must be completed with a letter grade.
Can we use Math 110 to replace the Math 54/EE 16A requirement by any chance?
Yes, it is dependent on the year you were admitted. :)
Hi, I was admitted in 2016, but took time off from Cal and I'll be returning next semester. In this case, does the math54/16a option work for me?

I think you answered your own question, as do the titles of the two sections. The three courses listed under "GPA/Prerequisites to Declare the CS Major" are requirements to declare the major. The lower division requirements are lower division courses that you are required to complete to graduate from Berkeley.

The page makes no reference to a sophomore year deadline to complete courses.
My bad, I thought lower division = 1st and 2nd year and upper division = 3rd and 4th year.

I'm confused on the "GPA/Prerequisites to Declare the CS Major" and the "Lower Division Requirements" sections on the lower division requirements webpage that was listed in this post. 

Does this mean that (for people admitted Fall 2017 or later) we MUST take Math 1A/B, EE 16A/B, and CS 61C before the end of sophomore year in addition to the 3 courses required for the declaration of the CS major, or can these courses be taken at any time throughout the 4 years?

history.content:
Please see our lower division requirements webpage. 

Students admitted to UC Berkeley before Fall 2017:

Students can choose from the following options:

  1. EE 16A (Designing Information Devices and Systems I)  and EE 16B (Designing Information Devices and Systems II)
  2. Math 54 (Linear Algebra and Differential Equations) and EE 16A (Designing Information Devices and Systems I) 
  3. Math 54 (Linear Algebra and Differential Equations) and  EE 16B (Designing Information Devices and Systems II)

Students admitted to UC Berkeley Fall 2017 or later:

  • EE 16A (Designing Information Devices and Systems I) or Math 54 (Linear Algebra and Differential Equations)*

  • EE 16B (Designing Information Devices and Systems II) is required

NOTE: Junior transfers who have an equivalent course to math 54, can take EE 16A p/np.
history.subject: LSCS major Lower Div EE requirements
